H.name: Hydrogen
H.description: The lightest and most abundant element in the universe.
H.funFact: Hydrogen is the only element that can exist without neutrons.

He.name: Helium
He.description: Noble gas used in balloons and cooling superconductors.
He.funFact: First detected in the solar spectrum before on Earth.

Li.name: Lithium
Li.funFact: Lightest metal and least dense solid element.

Be.name: Beryllium
Be.description: A hard, grayish metal naturally found in mineral rocks.

B.name: Boron
B.description: A brittle, black metalloid with high melting point.
B.discoveredBy: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard
B.funFact: Boron compounds are used to reinforce bulletproof vests.

C.name: Carbon
C.description: The basis of organic life; occurs in many allotropic forms like graphite and diamond.
C.funFact: Diamond and graphite are both pure carbon but look completely different.

N.name: Nitrogen
N.description: Makes up 78% of Earth's atmosphere; essential to life.
N.funFact: Liquid nitrogen is used to instantly freeze food and biological samples.

O.name: Oxygen
O.funFact: Liquid oxygen is magnetic and pale blue in color.

F.name: Fluorine
F.description: Most reactive element; forms compounds with nearly all others.
F.funFact: Fluorine is so reactive it can ignite hydrogen in the dark.

Ne.name: Neon
Ne.description: Inert noble gas famous for its use in neon signs.
Ne.funFact: Neon glows red-orange in discharge tubes.

Na.name: Sodium
Na.description: Soft, reactive metal stored under oil to prevent reaction with air.
Na.funFact: Explodes on contact with water due to rapid hydrogen gas formation.

Mg.name: Magnesium
Mg.description: Light metal that burns with a bright white flame.

Al.name: Aluminum
Al.funFact: Once considered more precious than gold!

Si.name: Silicon
Si.description: Second most abundant element in Earth's crust.
Si.funFact: The base of all modern electronics.

P.name: Phosphorus
P.description: Vital for life; found in DNA and bones.
P.funFact: Discovered from urine while searching for gold!

S.name: Sulfur
S.description: Bright yellow element with a distinct smell when burned.
S.funFact: Makes your fingers smell like rotten eggs when handled!

Cl.name: Chlorine
Cl.description: Greenish-yellow toxic gas with a strong odor.
Cl.funFact: Used as a chemical weapon in World War I.

Ar.name: Argon
Ar.description: Inert noble gas used in lighting and welding.
Ar.funFact: Makes up nearly 1% of Earth's atmosphere.

K.name: Potassium
K.description: Soft, silvery metal that reacts violently with water.
K.funFact: Essential for nerve transmission in your body.

Ca.name: Calcium
Ca.description: Essential mineral for bones and teeth.

Ti.name: Titanium
Ti.funFact: As strong as steel but 45% lighter!

V.name: Vanadium
V.funFact: Named after Vanadis, the Scandinavian goddess of beauty.

Cr.name: Chromium
Cr.description: Hard, steel-gray metal that takes a high polish.

Mn.name: Manganese
Mn.funFact: Essential for steelmaking - removes oxygen and sulfur.

Fe.name: Iron
Fe.description: Most widely used of all metals.

Co.name: Cobalt
Co.funFact: Gives blue color to glass and ceramics.

Ni.name: Nickel
Ni.description: Silvery-white lustrous metal with slight golden tinge.

Cu.name: Copper
Cu.description: Reddish, ductile metal with excellent conductivity.

Zn.name: Zinc
Zn.description: Bluish-white metal that tarnishes in air.
Zn.funFact: Essential for your sense of taste and smell!

Ga.name: Gallium
Ga.description: Soft, silvery metal that melts in your hand.
Ga.funFact: Melts in your hand (but won't boil until over 2000°C)!

Ge.name: Germanium
Ge.funFact: Predicted by Mendeleev before its discovery!

As.name: Arsenic
As.funFact: Known as the 'King of Poisons' in medieval times.

Se.name: Selenium
Se.description: Essential trace element but toxic in larger amounts.
Se.funFact: Named after the Greek word for Moon (Selene).

Br.name: Bromine
Br.description: Only liquid nonmetal at room temperature.

Kr.name: Krypton
Kr.description: Noble gas used in lighting and photography.
Kr.funFact: Used to define the length of a meter in 1960!

Sr.name: Strontium
Sr.description: Soft, silvery metal that burns red in fireworks.

Y.name: Yttrium
Y.funFact: Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden.

Zr.name: Zirconium
Zr.funFact: Zirconium oxide is used to make fake diamonds!

Nb.name: Niobium
Nb.funFact: Named after Niobe from Greek mythology.

Mo.name: Molybdenum
Mo.description: Hard, silvery metal with high melting point.
Mo.funFact: Essential for many enzymes in your body!

Tc.name: Technetium
Tc.funFact: No stable isotopes - all are radioactive!

Ru.name: Ruthenium
Ru.description: Rare transition metal of the platinum group.
Ru.funFact: Named after Ruthenia, the Latin name for Russia.

Rh.name: Rhodium
Rh.funFact: Most expensive precious metal (more than gold)!

Pd.name: Palladium
Pd.funFact: Can absorb 900 times its volume of hydrogen!

Ag.name: Silver
Ag.funFact: Best conductor of electricity of all elements!

Cd.name: Cadmium
Cd.discoveredBy: Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann and Friedrich Stromeyer
Cd.funFact: Named after the Latin word for calamine (cadmia).

In.name: Indium
In.discoveredBy: Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter

Sn.name: Tin
Sn.funFact: Gives a 'tin cry' when bent due to crystal structure.

Sb.name: Antimony
Sb.funFact: Symbol Sb comes from stibium, its ancient name.

Te.name: Tellurium
Te.funFact: Makes your breath smell like garlic!

I.name: Iodine
I.description: Shiny purple-black nonmetal that sublimes easily.

Xe.name: Xenon
Xe.description: Heavy noble gas used in lighting and anesthesia.
Xe.funFact: First noble gas found to form chemical compounds!

Ba.name: Barium
Ba.funFact: Makes X-rays of your digestive system visible!

Ce.name: Cerium
Ce.discoveredBy: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius, and Wilhelm Hisinger

Nd.name: Neodymium
Nd.description: Silvery-white metal that tarnishes in air.

Pm.name: Promethium
Pm.discoveredBy: Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, and Charles D. Coryell
Pm.funFact: Named after Prometheus who stole fire from the gods!

Gd.name: Gadolinium
Gd.funFact: Used in MRI scans to enhance images!

Tb.name: Terbium
Tb.funFact: Makes green phosphors in color TVs!

Dy.name: Dysprosium
Dy.funFact: Hard to get (name means 'hard to get at' in Greek)!

Ho.name: Holmium
Ho.funFact: Has the highest magnetic strength of any element!

Er.name: Erbium
Er.funFact: Makes fiber optic cables work better!

Lu.name: Lutetium
Lu.funFact: Last element in the lanthanide series and one of the hardest rare earth metals.

Hf.name: Hafnium
Hf.discoveredBy: Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy
Hf.funFact: Named after 'Hafnia', the Latin name for Copenhagen.

Ta.name: Tantalum
Ta.funFact: Named after Tantalus, a Greek mythological figure.

W.name: Tungsten
W.description: Hard, brittle, steel-gray metal with the highest melting point of all metals.
W.discoveredBy: Juan José Elhuyar and Fausto Elhuyar
W.funFact: Symbol 'W' comes from its old name, Wolfram.

Re.name: Rhenium
Re.discoveredBy: Walter Noddack, Ida Tacke, and Otto Berg
Re.funFact: One of the rarest elements in Earth's crust.

Ir.name: Iridium
Ir.funFact: Found in meteorites in higher concentrations than in Earth's crust.

Pt.name: Platinum
Pt.funFact: Used in the standard kilogram until 2019!

Au.name: Gold
Au.funFact: Edible (used in gourmet foods and drinks)!

Hg.name: Mercury
Hg.description: Shiny, silvery, liquid metal at room temperature.
Hg.funFact: Only metal liquid at room temperature!

Tl.name: Thallium
Tl.funFact: Extremely toxic—was used as a murder weapon in Agatha Christie novels!

Pb.name: Lead
Pb.funFact: Romans used it for plumbing (hence 'plumbing' from 'plumbum').

Bi.name: Bismuth
Bi.funFact: Least toxic heavy metal—used in stomach medicines!

Po.name: Polonium
Po.funFact: Named after Marie Curie's homeland, Poland!

At.name: Astatine
At.discoveredBy: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, and Emilio Segrè
At.funFact: Rarest naturally occurring element (less than 1 gram in Earth's crust at any time)!

Rn.name: Radon
Rn.funFact: Second-leading cause of lung cancer after smoking!

Fr.name: Francium
Fr.funFact: Most unstable naturally occurring element (half-life ~22 minutes)!

Ra.name: Radium
Ra.description: Highly radioactive, silvery-white alkaline earth metal.
Ra.funFact: Glows blue in the dark due to radioactivity!

Ac.name: Actinium
Ac.funFact: Glows blue in the dark (like radium)!

Th.name: Thorium
Th.funFact: Named after Thor, the Norse god of thunder!

Pa.name: Protactinium
Pa.discoveredBy: Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth Göhring
Pa.funFact: One of the rarest and most expensive naturally occurring elements!

U.name: Uranium
U.funFact: Named after Uranus, the planet discovered 8 years earlier!

Np.name: Neptunium
Np.discoveredBy: Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson

Pu.name: Plutonium
Pu.discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Edwin McMillan, Joseph W. Kennedy, and Arthur Wahl
Pu.funFact: Named after Pluto (like uranium for Uranus and neptunium for Neptune)!

Am.name: Americium
Am.discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, and Albert Ghiorso

Cm.name: Curium
Cm.discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, and Albert Ghiorso
Cm.funFact: Named after Marie and Pierre Curie!

Bk.name: Berkelium
Bk.discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, and Albert Ghiorso
Bk.funFact: Named after Berkeley, California (home of its discovery)!

Cf.name: Californium
Cf.discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, and Albert Ghiorso
Cf.funFact: One of the most expensive elements (millions per gram)!

Es.name: Einsteinium
Es.funFact: Discovered in debris from the first hydrogen bomb test!

Md.name: Mendelevium
Md.discoveredBy: Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, and team
Md.funFact: Named after Dmitri Mendeleev, creator of the periodic table!

No.name: Nobelium
No.funFact: Named after Alfred Nobel, founder of the Nobel Prize!

Lr.name: Lawrencium
Lr.funFact: Named after Ernest Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron!

Rf.name: Rutherfordium
Rf.funFact: Named after Ernest Rutherford, father of nuclear physics!

Db.name: Dubnium
Db.funFact: Named after Dubna, Russia (where it was first synthesized)!

Sg.name: Seaborgium
Sg.funFact: Named after Glenn T. Seaborg, Nobel laureate in chemistry!

Bh.name: Bohrium
Bh.discoveredBy: GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research
Bh.funFact: Named after Niels Bohr, pioneer of atomic structure!

Hs.name: Hassium
Hs.discoveredBy: GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research
Hs.funFact: Named after Hesse, Germany (where it was discovered)!

Mt.name: Meitnerium
Mt.discoveredBy: GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research
Mt.funFact: Named after Lise Meitner, co-discoverer of nuclear fission!

Ds.name: Darmstadtium
Ds.discoveredBy: GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research
Ds.funFact: Named after Darmstadt, Germany (where it was discovered)!

Rg.name: Roentgenium
Rg.funFact: Named after Wilhelm Röntgen, discoverer of X-rays!

Nh.name: Nihonium
Nh.funFact: First element discovered in Asia! (Name means 'Japan' in Japanese)

Fl.name: Flerovium
Fl.funFact: Named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions!

Lv.name: Livermorium
Lv.funFact: Named after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory!

Ts.name: Tennessine
Ts.funFact: Named after Tennessee, home to Oak Ridge National Lab!

Og.name: Oganesson
Og.funFact: Named after Yuri Oganessian, pioneer of superheavy elements!
